a. Multiple section courses in basic subjects -- particularly at the junior
college level -- can be taught by television to the student in his homey
making more effective use of limited faculties and facilities, Tele-
vision may be the principle method of instruction, or a supplement to
other methods, new or traditional. The teaching of classes by television
has been in use by the junior colleges of Chicago for several years.
b. With the growth of educational television stations and regional inter¬
connected networks, it becomes possible for several institutions to
join for the cooperative presentation on television of courses common
to them all, or for one institution to offer the course on television
for the benefit of enrolled students in many institutions.
In view of the fact that the continuance of existing community educational
television stations and the development of new community educational tele¬
vision stations is in the public interest, the Committee urges that a means
be found to assist these stations financially,.
California has established two outstanding community educational television
stations, in the San Francisco Bay Area and in Sacramento. These stations,
dependent upon public fund raising, have suffered and continue to suffer
from inadequate financing. The development of additional community stations
in other cities is deterred by a similar lack of financing.
a. The existence of community educational television stations is a major
asset to the State of California in the dissemination of information
about the process of state government and in the education of its
citizenry for responsible self-government.
b. The two existing community television stations have recently been joined
by microwave relay, providing the basis for a future statewide network
